body.p: Every now and then, someone asks me to explain what we get up to when we disappear to our house in France, usually with an overtone of puzzlement, if not downright bewilderment. What's the attraction of a somewhat battered house with no central heating in the middle of nowhere, hard to get to or from by public transport, and with nothing much to do in the immediate vicinity?

In August there's no need for explanation. Everyone, but everyone, heads for the countryside in August. And the people who live in the country? They head to the seaside, of course. We did that a few years ago, but this year we were very happy to just stay put in La Vergne. The weather was kind to us, and there were important amusements to attend.

Since we were starting from Bristol, we took the overland route by train which is reasonably speedy, but requires an overnight stay either in London or in Paris, since (as aforesaid) there is no useful train from Paris to La Souterraine after 0930. There used to be an early afternoon one, but it is no more. Yes, there are flights from Bristol to Paris, and no I do not want to take them: you are then faced with the problem of getting from Orly to Austerlitz, which is a horrible RER journey even when the metro is not on strike. Instead we have a pleasant evening at one of the Korean restaurants on the boulevard Saint Jacques, a good nights sleep in another forgettable Paris hotel (L'Orphée), and get up at a reasonable time of day. Lucy comes to meet us at La Souterraine as promised and allows us to make a whistle stop tour of the local Lidl as well. And here we are back home in La Vergne, which is still bearing traces of the rapid house cleaning I gave it back in May, all ready to resume doing nothing in particular for a few weeks. Has anything changed in our absence? Not visibly, unless you count weeds of which we have plenty, or tomatoes, which are much improved. The grass is parched, so I don't know where they are getting their refreshment from.

The ducks down at the shady end of the lake are in fine fettle when we go out for an evening stroll; the fish are occasionally to be seen leaping, and swooping birds may be observed to graze on hovering insects. It's a nice lake, frequented by occasional clumps of serious minded fishermen, some with battered vans groaning beneath the weight of their extensive fishing equipment, others who just came along for the ride. We grunt greetings to make them acknowledge our presence, which usually works. There is a nice view of the wooded hill beneath which the houses of La Vergne nestle and two pleasant walks into Bussière, one following the track of an old railway, the other following the crest of a hill. Et in arcadia ego.

Cousin Dave supplied me with a well-secured plastic tub of sourdough starter the last time I saw him, which I transported at the bottom of my baggage (another advantage of travelling by train). This enabled me to bake some really quite plausible bread as a change from the baguettes delivered by the local itinerant boulangère.

figure.head: Today's loaves are made with French flour and Australian rye starter

body.p: The 28th August is Saint Symphorien's day, patron saint of the commune of Bussière-Dunoise. Consequently, the end of the month is marked by a three day festival, of which the highlights included a procession of tractors pulling floral floats, lots of reasonably well behaved children, a Baby Schtroumpf roundabout and someone selling barbe a papa, competing marching bands, and much general jollity. If your French is up to it, the local paper gave it a good write up, and here are a few photos in any case.

figure.head: Les Majorettes de Saint Montrond, specially hired for the occasion

body.p: At the end of our stay we finally found a suitable weekend to go out for lunch with Evelyne, our local TAD conductrice, and a few of her favourite clients, as had been being proposed since the spring. The venue was a place called Toulx-Sainte-Croix, or more exactly Les Pierres Jaumatres, a hill on top of which there are some aesthetically remarkable large boulders and a very fine view, plus a huge chalet restaurant. The stones are apparently technically known as a chaos, and are the result of natural erosion, though that didn't stop various 19th century archaeologists claiming they were made by the druids. Georges Sand knew better, it says on this wiki page. My photos are here.

September time in previous years has been marked by masses of walnuts, but this year the harvest was frankly pathetic. Not enough rain or rain at the wrong time or just the cussedness of things, I dunno. The last raspberry of the season was also unimpressive, but there my expectations were much lower. Clearly a systematic pruning of everything is needed.
